elements.content: Four new polymeric metal compounds based on the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate ligand and different divalent cations (Co­(II), Cd­(II), Ba­(II)), including {[Co2(TTFTB)­(2,2′-Bpy)2­(H2O)2]·DMF·2H2O} n (1), {[Co2(TTFTB)­(4,4′-Bpy)­(H2O)6]·DMF} n (2), {[Cd­(H2TTFTB)­(Bpea)­(H2O)2]·DMF·3H2O} n (3), and {[Ba­(H2TTFTB)­(H2O)2]·DMF·C2H5OH} n (4) (2,2′-Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine, 4,4′-Bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine, Bpea = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane), were synthesized and characterized. The versatile redox-active tetracarboxylate ligand was coordinated to divalent metal ions in a multidentate fashion, forming different structures for complexes 1–4. Complex 1 exhibits a one-dimensional chain structure, whereas the 3-fold interpenetrating 3,4L13 net was observed in complex 2. Importantly, complex 3 displays a (3,8)-connected tfz-d net and complex 4 features a new (4,8)-connected three-dimensional topological network with a point symbol of (44.62)2­(48.64.816). The solid-state electrochemical properties and gas adsorption behaviors of 3 and 4 were subsequently investigated. Due to the incorporation of π-electron conjugated TTF rings into porous metal–organic frameworks, complexes 3 and 4 exhibit two reversible oxidation processes and adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2. These compounds enrich the study of redox-active porous materials.

elements.content: Four coordination polymers containing the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzolate ligand have been synthesized and characterized. The use of different coligands and metal ions results in distinct structures for these tetrathiafulvalene-based compounds. The 3D coordination polymers 3 and 4 show two reversible oxidation processes. Due to the large π-electron system from TTF units, adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2 is observed.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received great attention in recent decades owing to their high surface areas and tunable pore sizes, leading to versatile architectures with numerous potential applications. These include gas and small molecule storage, separation processes, catalysis, chemical sensing, structural determination, as well as electronic devices. However, the redox and electronic properties of three-dimensional MOFs have attracted relatively less attention in comparison with their adsorption properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received great attention in recent decades owing to their high surface areas and tunable pore sizes, leading to versatile architectures with numerous potential applications. These include gas and small molecule storage, separation processes, catalysis, chemical sensing, structural determination, as well as electronic devices. However, the redox and electronic properties of three-dimensional MOFs have attracted relatively less attention in comparison with their adsorption properties.

elements.content: The physical and chemical characteristics of ligands play a crucial role in dictating the properties of novel functional MOFs. Hence, the incorporation of redox-active ligands, such as tetrathiafulvalene (TTF), into coordination frameworks offers an effective strategy for the synthesis of redox-active materials. TTF is an unsaturated but nonaromatic organosulfur bis-heterocyclic moiety with two reversible and easily accessible oxidation states. In order to associate the functional unit with coordination complexes, a prominent redox-active class of compounds have been extensively studied in the fields of molecular conductors and superconductors. This resulted in a number of TTF-based complexes including monocarboxylate, dicarboxylate, and tetracarboxylate ligands. These types of coordination compounds containing TTF are also particularly attractive for fundamental electrochemical studies.

Hence, the incorporation of redox-active ligands, such as tetrathiafulvalene (TTF), into coordination frameworks offers an effective strategy for the synthesis of redox-active materials. TTF is an unsaturated but nonaromatic organosulfur bis-heterocyclic moiety with two reversible and easily accessible oxidation states. In order to associate the functional unit with coordination complexes, a prominent redox-active class of compounds have been extensively studied in the fields of molecular conductors and superconductors. This resulted in a number of TTF-based complexes including monocarboxylate, dicarboxylate, and tetracarboxylate ligands. These types of coordination compounds containing TTF are also particularly attractive for fundamental electrochemical studies.

elements.content: Although some coordination polymers comprising TTF-tetracarboxylate ligands have been synthesized, our focus is on MOFs constructed by larger rigid ligands. Recently, Dincă et al. reported the synthesis of the interesting TTF-tetrabenzoic acid (H4TTFTB) for the first time, and the zinc MOF based on it showing both permanent channels formed by benzoate bridges and columnar stacks of TTF rings. This TTF-based microporous MOF, which possessed an outstanding intrinsic charge mobility, demonstrates that employing π-stacks of electroactive building blocks as the charge transport pathway is an effective method for the synthesis of porous materials that display good conductivity and charge mobility. The advent of this class of complexes has promoted the development of the multifunctional properties of porous materials.

elements.content: Herein, we report four new coordination polymers based upon the versatile TTF-tetrabenzoate ligand with divalent metal ions (Co­(II), Cd­(II), Ba­(II)) and some neutral coligands (Schemes and ). The experimental results indicate that H4TTFTB is a fascinating ligand with versatility in the resulting coordination structures and redox properties. These multifunctional properties are investigated through the studies of the synthesis, structural characterization, and solid-state electrochemistry. Additionally, gas adsorption behavior is described in this paper.

elements.content: All the starting materials were commercially available and conducted in air. According to the literature method, tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate (H4TTFTB, H4L) was synthesized. The Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was used to collect powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data at room temperature. Infrared absorption spectra of compounds 1–4 were recorded on a Vector27 Bruker Spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. C, H, N, and S analyses were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using an STA 449C thermal analysis system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 conditions. Cyclic voltammetry measurements were performed in n-Bu4NPF6/CH3CN electrolyte using a BAS 100A electrochemical analyzer and three electrode system. All potentials are reported in mV versus Fc/Fc+ couple.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information

All the starting materials were commercially available and conducted in air. According to the literature method, tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate (H4TTFTB, H4L) was synthesized. The Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was used to collect powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data at room temperature. Infrared absorption spectra of compounds 1-4 were recorded on a Vector27 Bruker Spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. C, H, N, and S analyses were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using an STA 449C thermal analysis system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 conditions. Cyclic voltammetry measurements were performed in n-Bu4NPF6/CH3CN electrolyte using a BAS 100A electrochemical analyzer and three electrode system. All potentials are reported in mV versus Fc/Fc+ couple.

elements.content: The crystal statistics were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer equipped with a Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The cell parameters were retrieved and refined by using SMART and SAINT, respectively. The SADABS program was applied for absorption corrections. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program package SHELXL-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located in the Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic parameters. Some contribution of the electron density in these four compounds from the remaining solvent molecules was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON, which was determined by elemental analysis. Crystal data are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are given in Tables S1–S4 (). CCDC reference numbers are CCDC– 1040092 (1), 1040093 (2), 1040094 (3), and 1040095 (4). The topologies of complexes 2, 3, and 4 were performed using the program TOPOS with the CIF file. All the TOPOS results are shown in Table S5 ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography and Topological Analyses

The crystal statistics were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer equipped with a Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The cell parameters were retrieved and refined by using SMART and SAINT, respectively. The SADABS program was applied for absorption corrections. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program package SHELXL-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located in the Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic parameters. Some contribution of the electron density in these four compounds from the remaining solvent molecules was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON, which was determined by elemental analysis. Crystal data are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are given in Tables S1-S4 (). CCDC reference numbers are CCDC- 1040092 (1), 1040093 (2), 1040094 (3), and 1040095 (4). The topologies of complexes 2, 3, and 4 were performed using the program TOPOS with the CIF file. All the TOPOS results are shown in Table S5 ().

In the gas sorption measurements, all of the gases used were of 99.999% purity. Nitrogen (N2, at 77 K) and carbon dioxide (CO2, at 195 K) sorption experiments were measured on the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The MOF samples were activated prior to the measurements as follows. The as-prepared MOF crystals were immersed in anhydrous dichloromethane or methanol for several days to replace occluded solvents (mostly DMF). The solid was degassed via a temperature program of 10 °C/min to 120 °C for at least 24 h.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Analyses

In the gas sorption measurements, all of the gases used were of 99.999% purity. Nitrogen (N2, at 77 K) and carbon dioxide (CO2, at 195 K) sorption experiments were measured on the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The MOF samples were activated prior to the measurements as follows. The as-prepared MOF crystals were immersed in anhydrous dichloromethane or methanol for several days to replace occluded solvents (mostly DMF). The solid was degassed via a temperature program of 10 °C/min to 120 °C for at least 24 h.

elements.content: CoCl2·6H2O (9.6 mg, 0.04 mmol) and 2,2′-bipyridyl (6.2 mg, 0.04 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (2 mL) and H2O (2 mL). The solution was added to H4TTFTB (6.9 mg, 0.01 mmol) in 3:1 (v:v) DMF/ethanol (2 mL), and the mixture was heated at 75 °C for 72 h, yielding dark red square crystals. The crystals were washed with DMF and ethanol, followed by the addition of 10:13 (v:v) DMF:CH2BrCl. This resulted in the immediate formation of yellow impurities, which floated to the solvent surface while the remaining dark red square crystals sank. The impurities were removed, and this procedure was repeated in order to ensure the purity of the desired layer. The purified crystals were then collected. Yield: 20%. Anal. Calcd for C30H31­CoN3O8S2: C, 52.63; H, 4.56; N, 6.14; S, 9.37. Found: C, 52.31; H, 4.52; N, 5.98; S, 9.12. Selected IR data (KBr, cm –1): 3405­(m), 1667­(m), 1604­(m), 1539­(m), 1392(s), 1250­(m), 1015­(w), 763­(m).

elements.content: Four coordination polymers containing the TTF-tetrabenzoate ligand, including {[Co2(TTFTB)­(2,2′-Bpy)2­(H2O)2]·DMF·2H2O} n (1), {[Co2(TTFTB)­(4,4′-Bpy)­(H2O)6]·DMF} n (2), {[Cd­(H2TTFTB)­(Bpea)­(H2O)2]·DMF·3H2O} n (3), and {[Ba­(H2TTFTB)­(H2O)2]·DMF·C2H5OH} n (4), were successfully obtained. Their structures were distinct from each other despite being prepared using similar reaction conditions involving solvothermal methods. One reason for their differing structures is the potential for partial or complete deprotonation of the four carboxyl groups on the ligand which allow for rich coordination bonding and versatile structures with higher dimensions. In addition, the diverse coordination environments of metal ions, not only transition metals (CoII, CdII), but also alkaline earth metal ions (BaII), results in distinct structures due to their different ionic radii, as reported in the related literature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Four coordination polymers containing the TTF-tetrabenzoate ligand, including {[Co2(TTFTB)(2,2'-Bpy)2(H2O)2]⋅DMF⋅2H2O} n  (1), {[Co2(TTFTB)(4,4'-Bpy)(H2O)6]⋅DMF} n  (2), {[Cd(H2TTFTB)(Bpea)(H2O)2]⋅DMF⋅3H2O} n  (3), and {[Ba(H2TTFTB)(H2O)2]⋅DMF⋅C2H5OH} n  (4), were successfully obtained. Their structures were distinct from each other despite being prepared using similar reaction conditions involving solvothermal methods. One reason for their differing structures is the potential for partial or complete deprotonation of the four carboxyl groups on the ligand which allow for rich coordination bonding and versatile structures with higher dimensions. In addition, the diverse coordination environments of metal ions, not only transition metals (CoII, CdII), but also alkaline earth metal ions (BaII), results in distinct structures due to their different ionic radii, as reported in the related literature.

elements.content: The structures of these complexes show that the neutral ligands (2,2′-bipyridyl, 4,4′-bipyridyl, and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane) are good coligands for synthesizing metal complexes containing TTF ligands. These coordination polymers are insoluble in common solvents, including DMF. However, in the absence of an auxiliary ligand, side reactions easily occurred, and the pure crystals were difficult to obtain. In this work, we used a reported method for rapidly and effectively purifying the products that takes advantage of density differences. All bulk samples for property measurement were synthesized by repeating the density separation method using small fractions of solid samples. To ensure that the bulk materials were truly representative of the crystal structures, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out for 1–4 at room temperature. The experimental and simulated PXRD patterns are shown in Figures S1–S4 (), confirming the purity of the bulk synthesized materials. Thermogravimetric analysis experiments (Figures S5–S7, ) were also conducted to determine the thermal stability of these compounds.
elements.clean_text: The structures of these complexes show that the neutral ligands (2,2'-bipyridyl, 4,4'-bipyridyl, and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) are good coligands for synthesizing metal complexes containing TTF ligands. These coordination polymers are insoluble in common solvents, including DMF. However, in the absence of an auxiliary ligand, side reactions easily occurred, and the pure crystals were difficult to obtain. In this work, we used a reported method for rapidly and effectively purifying the products that takes advantage of density differences. All bulk samples for property measurement were synthesized by repeating the density separation method using small fractions of solid samples. To ensure that the bulk materials were truly representative of the crystal structures, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out for 1-4 at room temperature. The experimental and simulated PXRD patterns are shown in Figures S1-S4 (), confirming the purity of the bulk synthesized materials. Thermogravimetric analysis experiments (Figures S5-S7, ) were also conducted to determine the thermal stability of these compounds.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbcn space group with the asymmetric unit consisting of one Co­(II), a half ligand L4–, one chelating 2,2′-Bpy, and one coordinated water molecule. The cobalt ion in 1 exhibits a distorted octahedral coordination geometry completed by two nitrogen atoms (N1, N2) from a chelating 2,2′-Bpy, two oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from a chelating carboxyl group of L4–, one oxygen atom (O3) from another carboxylate ligand, and one oxygen atom (O5) from solvent water (Figure a). The Co–N and Co–O bond lengths are 2.102–2.121 and 2.060–2.288 Å, respectively, both of which are similar to those reported for Co­(II) complexes. The cobalt ions are linked by carboxylate groups on two sides of the TTF moiety into an infinite 1D chain along the crystallographic b axis. Adjacent chains are closely packed by intermolecular π···π interactions (d π···π = 3.722 Å) between the pyridine rings of 2,2′-Bpy, forming layers parallel to the ab-planes (Figure b). In the structure of 1, the hydrogen-bonded network is formed through the coordinated water molecules (O5) and the carboxylate group from the L4– ligand. Furthermore, the 2D networks are linked together by hydrogen bonds (d H5A···O3= 2.160(3) Å, ∠O5–H5A···O3 = 143.5(3)°; d H5B···O4 = 2.250(4) Å, ∠O5–H5B···O4 = 108.5(3)°) to yield the 3D supramolecular structure (Figure c). It is noted that 1D pore channels (12.6 Å × 14.5 Å) can be observed in the (001) direction due to the TTF-benzoate building blocks (Figure d).

elements.content: Compound 2 is a 2D coordination polymer which crystallizes in the trigonal P3121 space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one cobalt ion, a half ligand L4–, a half auxiliary ligand 4,4′-Bpy, and three coordinated water molecules. The cobalt ion is six-coordinated with the two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from two monodentate carboxyl groups, one nitrogen (N1) atom from 4,4′-Bpy, and three oxygen atoms (O5, O6, O7) from coordinated water molecules. It shows the slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a). The bond distances between coordinated water molecules and the cobalt ions (Co1–O5, Co1–O6, Co1–O7) are slightly longer (2.091–2.136 Å) than those to the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl groups (2.040–2.057 Å), whereas the Co–N bond length is 2.183 Å and is consistent with that reported for cobalt complexes in similar coordination environments. Each L4– in 2 links four cobalt ions to form infinite 1D chains via carboxylate bridges (Figure b). The 2D sheet structure of 2 is formed by bridging adjacent 1D chains via 4,4′-Bpy on two sides (Figure c). From the view of topology, each carboxylate ligand serves as a 4-connected node to link to four equivalent cobalt ions with a short vertex symbol (42·62·82). Similarly, each cobalt ion is bound to two carboxylate ligands and one 4,4′-Bpy ligand to act as a 3-connected node with a short vertex symbol (4·62). Thus, the point symbol for the (3,4)-connected binodal topological network is (4·62)2­(42·62·82), an example of the 3,4L13 net (Figure d). However, these two-dimensional sheets are stacked in a parallel fashion along [11̅0], [010], and [100] directions, respectively, to form an interesting 3-fold interpenetrated structure (Figure e and Figure S8, ).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, and the asymmetric unit consists of one cadmium ion, a carboxylate ligand H2L2–, one-half of the auxiliary ligand Bpea, and one coordinated water molecule. The cadmium ion in 3 exhibits a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, completed by one nitrogen atom (N1) from auxiliary ligands, four oxygen atoms (O2, O6, O7, O8) from four different carboxylate ligands, and one oxygen atom (O9) from a water molecule. The Cd–O bonds range from 2.245 to 2.265 Å, except for the oxo-bridged Cd–O6 bond, which is slightly longer than the normal bonds at 2.445 Å. The Co–N distance is 2.269 Å, which is consistent with that reported for similar cadmium complexes. Crystallographically equivalent Cd­(II) ions are linked together by carboxylates to form a dinuclear unit (-Cd-(O-C-O)2-Cd-) with a Cd–Cd distance of 4.875 Å (Figure a). The dinuclear units are connected by TTF anions to form 2D sheet motifs parallel to the bc-plane where the pore dimension of the rhomb channel is estimated to 10.6 Å × 15.2 Å (Figure b), and they are further linked by Bpea ligands along the a axis to give a 3D pillared layer-type network (Figure c,d,e). From the view of topology, each dinuclear cadmium unit is 8-connected by six carboxylate ligands and two adjacent dimeric units via the Bpea ligands with a short vertex symbol (46·618·84); each carboxylate ligand serves as a 3-connected node to link to three dinuclear units with a short vertex symbol (43). Thus, the point symbol for the (3,8)-connected binodal topological network is (43)2(46·618·84), referred to as the tfz-d net (Figure S9, ).

elements.content: The three-dimensional coordination polymer 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Ibam space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one barium ion, a half ligand H2L2–, and two coordinated water molecules. The barium ion is 10-coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from six different carboxylate ligands, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules. The Ba–O bond distances usually range from 2.681 to 2.842 Å, whereas the bond distances between the barium ions and the oxygen atoms from coordinated water are slightly longer (2.848–2.927 Å). The bond length of Ba–O1 is 3.193 Å, which is also observed in reported porous barium compounds. Due to the weak coordination bonding, Ba­(II) is 10-coordinate rather than the typical 8-numbered coordination mode (Figure a). Crystallographically equivalent Ba­(II) ions are linked together by carboxylates into a dinuclear unit (-Ba-(O-C-O)4-Ba-) with a Ba···Ba distance of 4.162 Å. In the 3D net, there are two types of channels marked as A (pore dimension: 10.8 Å × 11.2 Å) and B (pore dimension: 6.7 Å × 13.4 Å) (Figure b). Topological analysis indicates that it possesses a (4,8)-connected binodal topological network (Figure c). Each carboxylate ligand is linked to four equivalent [Ba2(COO)4] SBUs to act as a 4-connected node; each [Ba2(COO)4] SBU is bound by eight carboxylate ligands to act as an 8-connected node. To the best of our knowledge, the (4,8)-connected binodal topological network with a point symbol of (44.62)2(48.64.816) as a new topology has not been reported in TOPOS nor in the RCSR databases (Figure S10, ).

elements.content: The results confirm that organic polycarboxylate ligands exhibit a variety of connection modes with metal centers, making it possible for these ligands to provide abundant structural motifs for the construction of coordination polymers. In Zn2(TTFTB), reported by Dincă’s group, the TTFTB ligand has four deprotonated carboxylate groups with two different coordination modes: a bridging (μ2-η1:η1) mode and a chelating, bridging (μ2-η2:η1) mode. The four distinct coordination modes in 1–4 are illustrated in Figure . In the structure of 1, there are two types of carboxyl groups: two carboxylate groups act in a monodentate binding manner and the other two groups serve as a chelating mode. By comparison, in 2, the ligand L4– exhibits a tetra-monodentate binding mode. It should be noted that, in structures 3 and 4, only two carboxyl groups of the TTF ligand are deprotonated. Thus, for 3, this gives rise to three types of carboxyl groups: two act in a monodentate binding manner, one serves as a syn-syn μ2-η1:η1 coordinating group, and the other is not coordinated. In contrast, for 4, two carboxyl groups act in a monodentate binding manner and the other two serve as μ2-η2:η1 coordination modes. Hence, the ligand has four carboxyl groups which can be partially or completely deprotonated, leading to the variable structures with higher dimensions.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Modes of TTF-Tetrabenzoate Ligand

The results confirm that organic polycarboxylate ligands exhibit a variety of connection modes with metal centers, making it possible for these ligands to provide abundant structural motifs for the construction of coordination polymers. In Zn2(TTFTB), reported by Dincă's group, the TTFTB ligand has four deprotonated carboxylate groups with two different coordination modes: a bridging (μ2-η1:η1) mode and a chelating, bridging (μ2-η2:η1) mode. The four distinct coordination modes in 1-4 are illustrated in Figure . In the structure of 1, there are two types of carboxyl groups: two carboxylate groups act in a monodentate binding manner and the other two groups serve as a chelating mode. By comparison, in 2, the ligand L4- exhibits a tetra-monodentate binding mode. It should be noted that, in structures 3 and 4, only two carboxyl groups of the TTF ligand are deprotonated. Thus, for 3, this gives rise to three types of carboxyl groups: two act in a monodentate binding manner, one serves as a syn-syn μ2-η1:η1 coordinating group, and the other is not coordinated. In contrast, for 4, two carboxyl groups act in a monodentate binding manner and the other two serve as μ2-η2:η1 coordination modes. Hence, the ligand has four carboxyl groups which can be partially or completely deprotonated, leading to the variable structures with higher dimensions.

elements.content: Although many coordination polymers involving TTF redox-active ligands have been electrochemically characterized, the study of redox properties of the higher dimensionality coordination complexes with TTF ligands is limited due to their insolubility. In this paper, solid-state cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on complexes 3 and 4 to study their redox properties
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Electrochemistry

Although many coordination polymers involving TTF redox-active ligands have been electrochemically characterized, the study of redox properties of the higher dimensionality coordination complexes with TTF ligands is limited due to their insolubility. In this paper, solid-state cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on complexes 3 and 4 to study their redox properties

elements.content: The cyclic voltammogram of 3 (Figure ) displays no perceivable redox processes in the first anodic sweep. With subsequent cycles, however, two reversible oxidation processes at E 1/2 = 0.113 and 0.467 V become prominent and remain observable over multiple sweeps. These two processes are attributed to the oxidation of TTFTB to its radical cation and dication states, respectively. The oxidation waves only become apparent once the potential of 1.54 V is exceeded, resulting in a sharp surge in current. The linear correlation between the square root of scan rate and peak separation is indicative of slow kinetics (Figure ) typically associated with MOF materials.

elements.content: The cyclic voltammogram of 4 shows two poorly resolved oxidation processes upon the first anodic scan (Figure ). A subsequent sweep in the anodic region reveals two processes at E 1/2 = 0.095 and 0.450 V, which persist upon further cycling. In a similar manner to 3, these oxidation waves become more apparent when the sweep potential exceeds a threshold (1.30 V), resulting in subsequent rapid increases in current. The relationship between the square root of scan rate and peak separation (Figure b) is linear for the first oxidation step but is scan rate independent for the second process, indicating that the former is a diffusion controlled process.

elements.content: CO2 and N2 gas adsorption measurements were undertaken at 195 and 77 K, respectively, to examine the porosity of 3 and 4. As evidenced by the N2 adsorption isotherms, 3 shows a typical type II N2 isotherm (Figure ), indicating a surface-adsorption phenomenon. Interestingly, in the case of CO2 at 195 K, 3 exhibits a two-step uptake profile with a saturated uptake of approximately 30.5 mL/g. The initial steep uptake is likely due to the presence of intrinsic micropores, whereas the second step possibly arises from sliding of the 3D pillared layer-type nets, which opens up additional void space for CO2 molecules to diffuse in. It is most likely that this structural rearrangement causes a barrier for gas to diffuse out of the pores. Thus, it would appear that the use of a pillared layer motif for the synthesis of MOF 3 results in a hysteretic isotherm.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Behavior

CO2 and N2 gas adsorption measurements were undertaken at 195 and 77 K, respectively, to examine the porosity of 3 and 4. As evidenced by the N2 adsorption isotherms, 3 shows a typical type II N2 isotherm (Figure ), indicating a surface-adsorption phenomenon. Interestingly, in the case of CO2 at 195 K, 3 exhibits a two-step uptake profile with a saturated uptake of approximately 30.5 mL/g. The initial steep uptake is likely due to the presence of intrinsic micropores, whereas the second step possibly arises from sliding of the 3D pillared layer-type nets, which opens up additional void space for CO2 molecules to diffuse in. It is most likely that this structural rearrangement causes a barrier for gas to diffuse out of the pores. Thus, it would appear that the use of a pillared layer motif for the synthesis of MOF 3 results in a hysteretic isotherm.

elements.clean_text: 10  Gas sorption isotherms for 3 at low temperature (N2 at 77 K, CO2 at 195 K).

elements.content: The low temperature N2 adsorption experiment for 4 shows minimal uptake from the framework upon increasing pressure between 0 and 0.8 bar without hysteresis (Figure ). In contrast, the saturation CO2 adsorption amount for 4 at 195 K is approximately 59.5 mL/g. The steep initial rise in the adsorption of CO2 at extremely low pressures indicates the presence of intrinsic micropores in this compound. Since this compound has a stable framework, hysteresis is likely to originate from a kinetic sieving effect, whereby the kinetic diameter of CO2 causes hindered diffusion of CO2 through the pores. The adsorption selectivity of 4 toward CO2 over N2 may be a result of the combined influences of pore size and host–guest interactions. Due to the different quadrupole moment between CO2 and N2 molecules (−1.51 × 10–39 and −4.67 × 10–40 C m2, respectively), the electrostatic interactions between adsorbates and adsorbents for CO2 are much greater than those of N2. Herein, the aromatic rings including TTF units can enlarge the electron delocalized system. Thus, the host framework containing Ba­(II) ions and the large π-electron clouds from the TTF ligand gives rise to a rich electronic environment which favors strong CO2 interactions due to dipole–induced-dipole interactions, especially at low pressure. This result suggests that the material can potentially be useful for CO2 separation.

elements.content: In conclusion, a series of new coordination polymers containing the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzolate ligand were synthesized and structurally characterized. The versatile carboxylate ligand coordination modes allow them as different nodes (3-connected nodes in compound 3 and 4-connected nodes in compounds 1, 2, 4). The use of different metal ions results in the variable metal nodes (2-connected nodes in compound 1, 3-connected nodes in compound 2, and 8-connected nodes in compounds 3 and 4), eventually giving rise to these (3,4)-, (3,8)-, and (4,8)-connected topological networks. Gas adsorption measurements indicated adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2 due to the large π-electron clouds of TTF ligands in MOFs. The results suggest that the incorporation of redox-active ligands into coordination frameworks offers an effective strategy to engineer porosity and redox activity into framework systems leading to potential applications in electrical swing adsorption for gas separations. Owing to their potential for the construction of multifunctional materials, new TTF derivatives are of great interest to both the materials chemistry and supramolecular chemistry communities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a series of new coordination polymers containing the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzolate ligand were synthesized and structurally characterized. The versatile carboxylate ligand coordination modes allow them as different nodes (3-connected nodes in compound 3 and 4-connected nodes in compounds 1, 2, 4). The use of different metal ions results in the variable metal nodes (2-connected nodes in compound 1, 3-connected nodes in compound 2, and 8-connected nodes in compounds 3 and 4), eventually giving rise to these (3,4)-, (3,8)-, and (4,8)-connected topological networks. The redox properties of the coordination polymers 3 and 4 were investigated, and two reversible oxidation processes were observed. Gas adsorption measurements indicated adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2 due to the large π-electron clouds of TTF ligands in MOFs. The results suggest that the incorporation of redox-active ligands into coordination frameworks offers an effective strategy to engineer porosity and redox activity into framework systems leading to potential applications in electrical swing adsorption for gas separations. Owing to their potential for the construction of multifunctional materials, new TTF derivatives are of great interest to both the materials chemistry and supramolecular chemistry communities.

CoCl2·6H2O (9.6 mg, 0.04 mmol) and 2,2′-bipyridyl (6.2 mg, 0.04 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (2 mL) and H2O (2 mL). The solution was added to H4TTFTB (6.9 mg, 0.01 mmol) in 3:1 (v:v) DMF/ethanol (2 mL), and the mixture was heated at 75 °C for 72 h, yielding dark red square crystals. The crystals were washed with DMF and ethanol, followed by the addition of 10:13 (v:v) DMF:CH2BrCl. This resulted in the immediate formation of yellow impurities, which floated to the solvent surface while the remaining dark red square crystals sank. The impurities were removed, and this procedure was repeated in order to ensure the purity of the desired layer. The purified crystals were then collected. Yield: 20%. Anal. cln_elements.content:
CO2 and N2 gas adsorption measurements were undertaken at 195 and 77 K, respectively, to examine the porosity of 3 and 4. As evidenced by the N2 adsorption isotherms, 3 shows a typical type II N2 isotherm (Figure ), indicating a surface-adsorption phenomenon. Interestingly, in the case of CO2 at 195 K, 3 exhibits a two-step uptake profile with a saturated uptake of approximately 30.5 mL/g. The initial steep uptake is likely due to the presence of intrinsic micropores, whereas the second step possibly arises from sliding of the 3D pillared layer-type nets, which opens up additional void space for CO2 molecules to diffuse in. It is most likely that this structural rearrangement causes a barrier for gas to diffuse out of the pores. Thus, it would appear that the use of a pillared layer motif for the synthesis of MOF 3 results in a hysteretic isotherm.

The low temperature N2 adsorption experiment for 4 shows minimal uptake from the framework upon increasing pressure between 0 and 0.8 bar without hysteresis (Figure ). In contrast, the saturation CO2 adsorption amount for 4 at 195 K is approximately 59.5 mL/g. The steep initial rise in the adsorption of CO2 at extremely low pressures indicates the presence of intrinsic micropores in this compound. Since this compound has a stable framework, hysteresis is likely to originate from a kinetic sieving effect, whereby the kinetic diameter of CO2 causes hindered diffusion of CO2 through the pores. The adsorption selectivity of 4 toward CO2 over N2 may be a result of the combined influences of pore size and host–guest interactions. Due to the different quadrupole moment between CO2 and N2 molecules (−1.51 × 10–39 and −4.67 × 10–40 C m2, respectively), the electrostatic interactions between adsorbates and adsorbents for CO2 are much greater than those of N2. Herein, the aromatic rings including TTF units can enlarge the electron delocalized system. Thus, the host framework containing Ba­(II) ions and the large π-electron clouds from the TTF ligand gives rise to a rich electronic environment which favors strong CO2 interactions due to dipole–induced-dipole interactions, especially at low pressure. This result suggests that the material can potentially be useful for CO2 separation.

Gas Adsorption Behavior

CO2 and N2 gas adsorption measurements were undertaken at 195 and 77 K, respectively, to examine the porosity of 3 and 4. As evidenced by the N2 adsorption isotherms, 3 shows a typical type II N2 isotherm (Figure ), indicating a surface-adsorption phenomenon. Interestingly, in the case of CO2 at 195 K, 3 exhibits a two-step uptake profile with a saturated uptake of approximately 30.5 mL/g. The initial steep uptake is likely due to the presence of intrinsic micropores, whereas the second step possibly arises from sliding of the 3D pillared layer-type nets, which opens up additional void space for CO2 molecules to diffuse in. It is most likely that this structural rearrangement causes a barrier for gas to diffuse out of the pores. Thus, it would appear that the use of a pillared layer motif for the synthesis of MOF 3 results in a hysteretic isotherm. 

The low temperature N2 adsorption experiment for 4 shows minimal uptake from the framework upon increasing pressure between 0 and 0.8 bar without hysteresis (Figure ). In contrast, the saturation CO2 adsorption amount for 4 at 195 K is approximately 59.5 mL/g. The steep initial rise in the adsorption of CO2 at extremely low pressures indicates the presence of intrinsic micropores in this compound. Since this compound has a stable framework, hysteresis is likely to originate from a kinetic sieving effect, whereby the kinetic diameter of CO2 causes hindered diffusion of CO2 through the pores. The adsorption selectivity of 4 toward CO2 over N2 may be a result of the combined influences of pore size and host-guest interactions. Due to the different quadrupole moment between CO2 and N2 molecules (-1.51 × 10-39 and -4.67 × 10-40 C m2, respectively), the electrostatic interactions between adsorbates and adsorbents for CO2 are much greater than those of N2. Herein, the aromatic rings including TTF units can enlarge the electron delocalized system. Thus, the host framework containing Ba(II) ions and the large π-electron clouds from the TTF ligand gives rise to a rich electronic environment which favors strong CO2 interactions due to dipole-induced-dipole interactions, especially at low pressure. This result suggests that the material can potentially be useful for CO2 separation.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 1: (a) a coordination sphere around the Co­(II) center showing the six-membered coordination geometry; (b) adjacent 1D chains forming the 2D sheet by virtue of π···π stacking of alternating 2,2′-Bpy aromatic cores; (c) the layered supramolecular hydrogen-bonding structure in the crystal; (d) a view of the benzoate-lined pores down the c axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1: (a) a coordination sphere around the Co(II) center showing the six-membered coordination geometry; (b) adjacent 1D chains forming the 2D sheet by virtue of π⋅⋅⋅π stacking of alternating 2,2'-Bpy aromatic cores; (c) the layered supramolecular hydrogen-bonding structure in the crystal; (d) a view of the benzoate-lined pores down the c axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 2: (a) a coordination sphere around the Co­(II) center showing the six-membered coordination geometry; (b) an infinite chain linked by carboxylate bridges; (c) the 2D sheet structure; (d) the corrugated topology network (blue line: tetracarboxylate ligand; red line: 4,4′-Bpy); (e) a perspective view of the 3-fold interpenetrating net. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 3: (a) a coordination sphere around the Cd­(II) center showing the six-membered coordination geometry and the dinuclear unit; (b) the 2D sheet constructed from L2– and Cd­(II) ions; (c) the 1D chain constructed from Bpea and dinuclear units; (d) the pillared-layer structure constructed from 2D sheets and Bpea; (e) the corrugated topology network (red line: tetracarboxylate ligand; blue line: the Bpea auxiliary ligand; blue colored node for tetracarboxylate ligand; green colored node for Cd2 clusters). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
